page.title: 16Local history Chaldon Hills
page.content: Evidence of ancient man's occupation of the block is clearly visible.In the South-West corner is a Field System including a steeply sided valley which is thought to have been a Roman vineyard. In the South-East corner near Belhuish there are three bowl round barrow burial mounds, each approximately 12 metres diameter and 0.3 metre high. Marley Wood, in the North-East corner is an ancient wood planted by the Romans or Saxons. It was possibly originally used for coppicing Ash. In the South-East corner near Burngate Farm are the remains of a house known as Mount Poynings. This was built between 1540 and 1544 by Thomas Poynings (who owned the Lulworth Estate) using stone from the former Bindon Abbey near Wool.
